entry.title: Combined summary - Making fee estimation better
entry.summary: The discussions surrounding Bitcoin technology have focused on the need for better fee estimation and decreasing the need for recovery. The goal is to make techniques like signing multiple transactions with different fee levels less useful by improving fee estimation. Various factors such as size, type, age, number of inputs vs outputs, output amounts, miner fee policies, and actual competing transactions on the blockchain need to be considered while estimating fees. However, if the basis for calculating the fee is not fundamentally compatible with relay and transaction-inclusion policies being run by large mining pools, it may result in contention that bumps out of a few blocks. Wallets should handle double-spends gracefully to make transaction replacement user-friendly; otherwise, users will have to constantly monitor tx propagation and recreate their transactions with different fees, which would make many use cases inconvenient.There have been suggestions made by various developers to improve fee estimation, such as "actively bidding" for fees using replacement due to block contention and advertising fees paid in coinbase. In addition, wallets should be able to handle double-spends gracefully to make transaction replacement user-friendly. However, this feature could be inconvenient for many use cases, such as half-offline Bluetooth transactions, users with unstable connections or power concerns on hardware wallets. Overall, there needs to be ongoing efforts to optimize blockchain technology and make it more efficient for users.In 2013, the Bitcoin community discussed the upcoming changes to fee estimation for version 0.9 of Bitcoin. Gavin Andresen suggested that fee estimation was an API that provides data points with parameters including processing time and confidence levels. He recommended a blog post for a high-level overview and a pull request on GitHub for low-level details and discussion. The proposed changes were not intended as the one true solution for transaction fees and prioritization, but rather as a starting point.There were concerns about out-of-band (OOB) fee payments disrupting fee estimation code, but it was determined that they would have little effect. Additionally, wallets would need to handle double-spends gracefully to make transaction replacement user-friendly. There were also discussions about the inconvenience of constantly monitoring transaction propagation and recreating transactions with different fees for wallets. This could create issues for half-offline Bluetooth transactions, users with unstable connections or lost battery power, and hardware wallets on the bitcoincard due to power concerns. However, it was acknowledged that combining fee estimation with some form of transaction replacement was necessary to give users a way to recover from bad estimates.The email exchanges from 2013 revolve around various aspects of Bitcoin transactions, including fee estimation and transaction prioritization. In one discussion, Gavin Andresen and Peter Todd talk about aggressive mempool expiration and the need for wallets to handle double-spends gracefully. They also suggest the possibility of wallets creating and signing three transactions with different fees at once. In another email thread, Peter Todd proposes a way to improve blockchain-based fee estimates in out-of-band mining contracts by having miners advertise what fees were actually paid. However, concerns are raised about some miners' business models and the potential for private transactions affecting the estimates.Overall, the discussions highlight the complexities involved in determining and implementing effective fee structures within blockchain technology. It is noted that the entire ecosystem of wallets needs to be considered in order to make transaction replacements user-friendly. The goal should be to ensure that all wallets can handle double-spends gracefully. In addition, there is a discussion about the equivalence of miners and their differences in transaction acceptance policies. It is suggested that a customer might want an exclusive contract with a miner for non-standard transactions that have to be submitted directly to them. It is also emphasized that if a transaction is broadcasted, it should get mined in a short order, or otherwise things are going wrong.Gavin Andresen recommends looking into fee estimation as an API that provides data points with parameters including processing time and confidence levels. He also asks for resources on transaction fee theories and their correlation with network security. Ultimately, the email exchanges emphasize the need for ongoing development and improvements in the Bitcoin ecosystem.
